title: Can a bad singer become a good singer? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m working on a startup to help bad singers become good singers, because I know it’s usually possible! First… music psychology research shows that only 1.5% of the population has amusia, which is brain-based “tone deafness.” Some others have beat deafness, or speech disorders, but otherwise the problem is lack of training. Second, I’ve seen two methods so far that work. The Kodaly method, which I learned as a kid, can teach singing to every kid. At 150 Hungarian “singing schools” where it was taught from kindergarten on, everyone sang. And in Japan, Dr. Toru Yuba developed “the Yuba method” based on his theories about “singing muscles” not being coordinated. I’m in the process of adapting these and other insights with the help of some tech. Singing is a skill sometimes enhanced by talent, but it’s a skill that improves with training. It requires you to focus on music in a different way, and use a whole bunch of muscles in a different way. But it gets better with training and practice! fwiw I was the entrepreneur of a cappella for 16 years, a tech VC for 11 years, and a startup mentor for 8 years. If you’re interested in going from bad to good singer, let me know!

Of course, man! Everybody can get better in all the aspects of singing…it’s just it requires time. In fact, the transformation of a really bad singer in a decently good singer requires a lot of time, frequently years. Here I list a bunch of aspects of singing and what means “get better” in each one. Tuning: the skill of singing a specific note. Be tuned can be learned, it depends on your musical ear and how well you control your phonatory system.Range: how far can you go, how high and how low are the sounds you are able to produce. It’s practice, but there’s always a limitation in each singer; nobody can sing all the notes in music.Flexibility (or singing acrobatics, as I call it): the capability of making some stranges and complicated melismas.Sustain: how much time you can keep a single note, in an audible way.Volume-resonance (you can imagine yourself what this aspect is all about): the power of your voice, in terms of loudness and resonators. Your whole body resonates, but face and chest are especially good at this.Performing: how much soul you put in your singing.There’s a lot of other things you can improve in singing, with months or years of practice, but the last one I listed is the harder: if you can’t communicate emotions at the beginning of your training, if you can’t be real…man, in that case, the evolution has to be not just in the techniques, but also in you.

I think it really depends on the situation. If someone is genuinely tone deaf, it can be nigh impossible to train. It certainly wouldn't be a simple case of voice lessons. There would need to be a lot of ear training and even more patience and daily practice for the student. If being tone deaf isn't an issue, voice lessons and practice will help immensely. It's necessary that the student practice daily, bring a device or have an app to record the lesson and to record the practice sessions to be able to correct and improve technique. It is possible to become a better singer - I don't know about good simply because good is a pretty loose term - but it will take a lot of discipline and work on your side.

Of course they can, they just need the correct training. Do not trust videos on the Internet, half of the “vocal coaches” are fakes and try to be know-it-alls when in reality they don't know the first thing about singing. If your like me and don't have the money to pay for singing lessons, I'd look for a good paying job unless your too young then ask your parents to pay for you to have singing lessons for you birthday, therefore they'd have time to save up. For me, I got singing lessons for free at my school, they paid for it as I took music for a GCSE and can't afford singing lessons. Some schools will do that as well.

You certainly can, yes! I’ve known many people who (with the right tutoring) now have amazing voices. I suggest you look for a good teacher, who will help you develop your voice. Make sure you’ll be taking care of your voice too (drinking loads of water, not constantly screaming or straining your voice, etc.) One thing to remember - persevere. As you will be starting from scratch, you will want to give up many times. But trust me, everything will pay off. Best of luck!

Absolutely! Singing is learned like anything else. I never sang until I was 27, getting my degree in music. By 29 I was singing regularly, and even making money as both a choral and popular music. I started out not being able to sing much at all, and with a few years studying under several phenomenal professors, I was able to sing clean, high, and in tune.

Yes. A lot of legendary American singers have ‘unorthodox’ voices. Prince, Bob Dylan, Mick Jagger, Bobby McFerrin, James Hetfield, Alanis Morisette and LL Cool J. Good songwriting, honest lyrics and interesting arrangements are often more powerful than ‘great’ voices.

This is a copy pasta of my answer to the question “Can I learn singing at the age of 18?” I hope this helps. First of all, age is not concerned to singing at all. It depends on how much of efforts and dedication you put into singing. If you’re starting to practice in recent time, I would suggest you to start exploring your voice first. Know your key, perfect pitch and singing style. Depending upon your voice i.e whether alto, tenor, soprano choose songs that are easy to sing. Easy to sing in the sense, no too high notes and no too low notes with basic vibratos. Practice singing the note sequence everyday and trying matching them exactly to the song. Use your sense of rhythm to learn. If you think you’re out of rhythm, try using beats like snaps and claps. When you feel you’re ready with the notes and rhythm, try singing a bit higher keys and complex vibratos. As this continues, practice daily and in no time you’ll be good at it. Cheers!
You can train anyone to sing, but true talent isn't something that's taught; it's innate. You can't squeeze water from a rock. You either have it or you don't.

Not being good at singing merely means you have to work more hard than people who can sing a bit. Every one can sing. You can talk to music schools near you. Watch beginners video on online platforms. I have seen people who knew nothing about music transforming into Beautiful vocalists. All you need is practice and dedication. And there you go!
